title: Diploma in Intellectual Property
headline: Learn about important intellectual property rights such as copyright, patents, trademarks and trade secrets.
description: This free online Diploma in Intellectual Property Rights gives a detailed explanation of the types of intellectual property. Copyright describes the rights creators have to their artistic and literary works. Patents are exclusive rights granted over an invention or industrial process, and they protect against unauthorized use of the product. Trademarks are signs that are meant to be used in commerce as they distinguish one company's goods.
courseDescription:
This free online course provides a Diploma in Intellectual Property Rights, and starts with a brief introduction to IP (Intellectual Property). IP is a category of property that includes intangible creations of the human intellect. There are many types of intellectual property, and some countries recognize more than others. The most well-known types are copyrights, patents, trademarks, and trade secrets.

The course shall give a brief overview of the IP landscape in India. It shall also dwell into the role of IP in the modern intangible economy. There has been rise in the intangible economy especially in the last few decades. The protections that IP rights offer give people a way to benefit financially from or earn recognition for their creations. The right balance between creator interests and the interests of the wider public fosters an environment in which innovation and creativity flourish.

Next we will learn about types of intellectual property. Copyright describes the rights creators have to their artistic and literary works. Patents are exclusive rights granted over an invention or industrial process, and they protect against unauthorized use of the product. Trademarks are signs that are meant to be used in commerce as they distinguish one company's goods or services from those of other companies. Trade secret laws are designed for the protection of sensitive business information. This course can be offered as a generic elective subject under the Choice Based Credit System in universities.

Start Course Now

All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:

  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:

  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain intellectual property.
    • Discuss the two ways that rights can be used.
    • Recognize the property and intellectual in intellectual property rights and discuss.
    • Identify the common characteristics in intellectual property.
    • List the kinds of Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) and their duration.
    • Identify the rights granted by intellectual property.
    • Describe the origin of intellectual property.

  • The Origin of Intellectual Property - Part 1

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Intellectual property relates to original ideas, results that emanate from research, and generally it covers some kind of critical business information.
    • Intellectual property specifically refers to things that emanate from human creative labour.
    • A right is a legal entitlement which is recognized and can be protected and the violation of which is deemed as 'unlawful' and leaves the right-holder with a remedy.
    • Rights can be used in two ways; liberty and license.
    • Infringement technically means trespass.
    • Property is a form of regulation. Property can be either public property or private property.
    • Public property is something which is held in common, private property is something which a person holds for himself individually.
    • 'Intellectual' refers to a product that come out of our intellect. Intellect is our ability to think and understand ideas
    • Inventions are products of creative human labour.
    • Registration is done by the government or by the state. Registration confers sanctity over the intellectual property right.
    • Copyright gives the creator the right to make more copies in different forms

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Identify how intangible rights work in an intangible economy.
    • Recognize what makes an asset and intangible asset.
    • List and explain the policy challenges in an intangible economy.
    • Discuss how Novartis case is an important case in patent law.
    • Describe the Novartis standard which was decided by the Supreme Court in the Novartis case.
    • Identify the three criterias for startup.

  • Definition of Start-up

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Investment refers to the spending that creates fixed assets.
    • Capital can be considered as a fixed asset providing for productive services.
    • A patent is an intangible asset.
    • The first trait as economists tells us is scalability. The intangible asset is scalable.
    • Policymakers should understand that intangible assets are contested.
    • Novartis case is an important case in patent law.
    • The court held that the efficacy criteria that Novartis had put forward was not sufficient to demonstrate enhanced efficacy.
    • The Intellectual Property Appellate Board also upheld the decision of the patent office rejecting the patent for Novartis.
    • Startup was defined through three criteria; the date of incorporation or registration, turnover and startup.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • List the process of registration of patents in India.
    • Identify the patents that need to be filed and the ones that do not.
    • Explain when and how to file a patent.
    • Identify who can apply for a patent.
    • List the requirements and types of a patent application.

  • Who can Apply for a Patent

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • The process of registration starts with a person filing a patent application before the patent office and the patent office scrutinizing the application for certain checks.
    • Patents offer an exclusive monopoly right.
    • Filing a patent gives the patentee or the patent owner, the right to work in a particular sphere to the exclusion of others.
    • Patents are also seen as instruments that can incentivize innovation by offering a limited monopoly for the inventor.
    • Patents can be granted only for an invention that pertains to a field of technology.
    • Patentability refers to the ability of an invention to be granted a patent.
    • Some intellectual property rights like the patent right requires an application to be filed before the patent office.
    • A copyright notice does not require registration. Registration of copyright is optional.
    • In the patent application, the timing of filing the patent application is critical because all countries like India now follow the first to file principle. Now, globally we have one standard which is the first to file principle.
    • A provisional application can be filed. The provisional has to have a disclosure which can cover the entire invention that you have come up with.

  • Lesson Summary
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the term patent prosecution.
    • Identify the rights that accrue on the holder of the patent.
    • State the restrictive conditions are referred to in section 140 of the Patents Act.
    • Describe opposition to patents.
    • Explain how we determine infringement.
    • State the defenses that can be taken in an infringement suit.
    • Outline the duties of the Intellectual Property Appellate Board.
    • List two types of declaratory suits that can be filed with regard to patents.
    • Explain the types of compulsory licenses.
    • Discuss government use and acquisition of patents.
  • Patent Prosecution - Part 1

  • Lesson Summary
    • Prosecution means the continuation of a course of action which results in something.
    • The patent application is kept confidential, it is not published because of certain international arrangements where the applicant we will get 18 months to decide which jurisdictions the applicant needs to enter.
    • Novelty means they should not be any disclosure of your invention before filing the patent application.
    • From the date of publication, there are rights that the applicant can claim as though he had a patent granted in his name.
    • Litigation can only be started at the time after the grant. Till such time no litigation can take place.
    • Your claim for damages is going to be based on the fact that the infringer infringed your invention; and your invention is as you have described in your claims.
    • The patent applicant can also claim for royalty in some cases where they were some acts of infringement that were committed during the pendency of his application.
    • When a patent is granted, there are certain rights that accrue on the holder of the patent, the patentee. The exclusive right is a right to prevent third parties. An exclusive licensee becomes a person who can exercise the
      rights of the owner.
    • When a patent is granted a patent it can be assigned to another person.
    • There are certain restrictive conditions that have to be avoided in any contract or agreement pertaining to patents. These conditions are referred to in section 140 of the patents act.
  • Lesson Summary

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Distinguish between trade mark and business.
    • Discuss how brands communicate information with regard to a product using frozen dessert market as a case study.
    • Describe the international arrangements on trade marks.
    • Explain the laws that govern the trade mark laws in India.
    • State the distinguishing features between a trade mark that is registered, and a trade mark that is not registered.
    • Identify the effects of registering a trade mark.
  • Trade Marks

  • Trade Marks in India

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Trade Marks in India

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Trade Marks refer to marks that are used in trade. These marks are used to identify or distinguish goods and services that are used in business.
    • A business can be defined as, an organization or an economic system, where goods and services are exchanged for one another or money.
    • Trade marks are used solely in business activities or the use or the evolution of trade marks came around in business activities. Trade marks came up as a means to promote and sell goods and services.
    • A trade mark refers to any word, name, symbol or device which are used to identify and distinguish goods and services.
    • Legal protection for trade marks started around the 16th Century, when traders used it to signify the source.
    • Most of the arrangements started off with the Paris Convention in 1883, that is the point at which there was a need to have an international arrangement on trademarks.
    • International registration came about with the Madrid Agreement.
    • The Paris Convention in 1883 brought out the principle of national treatment.
    • Initially there was a provision under the Indian Penal Code, these were the provisions by which if someone used a mark without authorization that was regarded as a criminal offence.
    • While filing an infringement suit, the person who owns the mark can file the infringement suit at the place at which he resides.
  • Lesson Summary

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain briefly what copyright is.
    • Discuss the history of copyright law.
    • State the criteria for protection of a copyright.
    • List the different types of assignment.
    • Identify educational exceptions in copyright law in India.

  • Subject Matter

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Subject Matter

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Subject Matter

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Copyright can literally be construed as the right to make further copies.
    • The copyright is an exclusive right which is given by the law which extends to a period of time.
    • Copyright can vest on the authors, composers, artists or creators of artistic, literary, dramatic or any form of creative work.
    • Copyright subsists in original works.
    • In copyright law originality refers to the fact that it is unique in the sense that it originated from the author.
    • Copyrights are granted by the mere fact that they are created and originality questions on originality would arise only when there is an infringement and there are challenges made to the copyright.
    • Copyright came out of the necessity for creators to profit from their work.
    • Piracy also played a role in having the copyright laws in place. Piracy was regarded as plundering of intellectual property.
    • In India initially we had the Indian Copyrights Act in 1914 which was brought in by the Britishers and post independence we had the Copyright Act of 1957.
    • Fixation refers to the fact that the material or the product on which the copyright exist should be recorded in a material form, it should be capable of being fixed to something.
    • To denote that something is a subject matter of copyright, we use the symbol C within a circle.
